newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korea police pin second death on students - report.
newsitem.headline: S.Korea police pin second death on students - report.

text.p: South Korean police on Thursday blamed radical student leftists for the death of a man whose body was found at a university campus in the southwest city of Kwangju last month, newspapers and television said.
The leading Chosun Ilbo newspaper reported that police suspected Lee Jong-kwon, 25, had been beaten by students who thought he was a police informant.
If proved true, it would be the second case of militant students beating to death suspected police spies.

The outlawed student body Hanchongryon took responsibility last week for the death of 22-year-old Lee Suk, a factory worker who died from beatings by students trying to extract a written confession that he was an informant.
The Chosun Ilbo reported that Kwangju police were searching for about 10 students in connection with the new case.

It said Lee Jong-kwon was found dead on May 27 at Chunnam National University's student union building. An autopsy showed he had been hit by a "dull object" and was badly bruised on his limbs and shoulder and had two broken ribs.
Earlier on Thursday, 31 militant students went on hunger strike in protest against a government crackdown on the pro-Pyongyang Hanchongryon, witnesses said.
The students chained themselves to a steel rail along a ramp in the Roman Catholic Church in Seoul's Myongdong area. The cathedral is a traditional sanctuary for anti-government protesters.
"We have decided to stage an indefinite hunger strike because the government is using the death of two people as an excuse to suppress the student movement," their spokesman told Reuters.
One policeman was also killed while trying to end a violent street demonstration by the group.
State prosecutors on Tuesday ordered the arrest of scores of Hanchongryon leaders and formally banned the group, which the government maintains takes orders from Pyongyang.
The militant group has called for the resignation of President Kim Young-sam and the reunification of the Korean peninsula under a formula suggested by communist North Korea.

"The Kim Young-sam regime is trying to avert a political crisis by cracking down on the Hanchongryon. It is trying to divert public attention from a scandal over the over-spending in the 1992 presidential elections," the spokesman said.
Opposition parties have claimed the president massively over-spent to get elected, and are demanding a full accounting.
Police have arrested three Hanchongryon activists over the fatal beating of Lee Suk.
